body: LGTM.

Note on your aside: you will not need to rebase. The commits d510b4e, 8bce693, and 9f8dd18 will simply be added to GitHub and the master pointer updated. Then it will automatically look like the PR you intend.

Also, performing an "offline" review of the new changes and pushing is perfectly safe. I found it easiest to read the changes via `git diff --stat apache/master github/pr/72`.

LGTM, though the Jenkins failure looks like it might be a real breakage of some sort.

The changes LGTM.

Travis passes fully, but Jenkins fails only on the archetypes. I spent an hour trying to fix, but was not successful, and it looks like the cause may be related to the `-incubating` suffix and artifact resolution that was discussed ad nauseum on the list.

I think that in the interest of getting the big move in we should go ahead and merge, and fixup the Jenkins archetype issue as we go. It may require updating the version of Maven in Jenkins.

asfgit is still slow, but this has been merged.

Travis is still useful as a signal of build success, and jenkins results should be manually inspected.
And I've filed https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-148 for the Jenkins test issue.
Nice. This makes things so much cleaner.
Thanks @dhalperi and @kennknowles.
Thanks Davor, much appreciated !

I don't think this comes from the Flink Runner. By default, the examples write to a user-specified path or to the project basedir (which would be `runners/flink/examples`). Would be nice to find out where the directory is created...
Interesting. I first confirmed that after building the Flink runner and examples I don't see the folder. And then `mvn install` did not produce the folder. So I am going to just close this PR.
R: @dhalperi

Are there better and more consistent names? 
1. ContingInput.withRate(long, Duration)
It is not clear if withRate(100, 10) and withRate(50, 5) are the same or not. There is also issue of dividedBy()
I suggests something like: withMinimalGap() withMinGap(), withInputGap(), withElementGap()
1. CountingSource.withPeriod(Duration)
   Period is not clear.
   And, I suggests to the the same name as ContingInput.

R: @kennknowles
Jenkins failure is a known breakage not related to this PR.
Jenkins failure is a known breakage not related to this PR.

## [Current coverage](https://codecov.io/github/apache/incubator-beam?ref=aaebdb2a992d783c8e81002930e52edf89497155) is `71.46%`

> Branch **#89** has no coverage reports uploaded yet.
> 
> No diff could be generated. No reports for `master` found.
> 
> Powered by [Codecov](https://codecov.io). Updated on successful CI builds.

I think rate is the best name for this, for a couple of reasons - the biggest is that rate is a common term used for time-based deltas; the other is that gap suggests that there is a consistent space between outputs, which is not true - the aggregate rate at any given time after source evaluation starts should approach and not exceed the specified rate, but we make no guarantees about how elements are grouped within that range (and in fact cannot, as that is partially left up to the runner for when it schedules the source).

I have changed the CountingSource#withPeriod to CountingSource#withRate, in part due to the potential impossibility to get an accurate period that satisfies the rate.

Overall, looks pretty good. I'd like to see some more comments -- lots of things going on in this file -- and more sanity checks.

I'd like to see some end-to-end tests of BigQueryIO.Write -- e.g., the write data is actually written.

LGTM

LGTM
Okay, BEAM-85 really is the issue I was thinking of. Geeze.

LGTM.

One consideration off the top of my head: one reason we process a whole `KeyedWorkItem` at once is so we can eagerly merge together session windows. Essentially a keyed work item represents a whole bundle so the `ReduceFnRunner` can go aggregate work. This is less of an issue than it used to be since we re-use state cells and windows instead of  building an unbounded tree of merged windows. @mshields822 might have more to suggest.

Jenkins failure is a known issue with a conflict between local spark endpoint configuration and our GCE workers. We are investigating, but it should not block progress.
Replaced the implementation of "do we have available elements", which is a reasonably significant change to how the decision is made. PTAL.
I close this PR to open one PR per IO.
Made PubsubGrpcClient public and refactored a bit so that it API is free of gRPC and protoc dependencies. This means it can be reused, and also will make mocking easier.
Left a (minor) few comments. The only real one is that I'd prefer `sdks/java/io` as opposed to top-level `io`, given that all IOs are SDK-specific.
Merged. Thanks JB!
My guess is this would be easier done if first move CountingSource into CountingInput -- reduce some of the extra code you had to write to get around things.
LGTM.

There are other alternatives, like coveralls.io, proposed [here](https://github.com/GoogleCloudPlatform/DataflowJavaSDK/commit/de2dafe3686e27139720e1c8304d4d10aebdb69f).

I'm not sure which one is better, but I prefer the concept of the Maven plugin more than executing random scripts outside the build process. All other things being equal (which is probably not the case), I'd prefer that approach.
